unnormalised: Hey everyone, someone asked about time zones in India and how they work, so figured I’d give a quick explanation. It’s actually simpler than you might think! India officially follows Indian Standard Time (IST), which is GMT+5:30. This means we're always 5 and a half hrs ahead of Greenwich Mean Time. So, if it’s 12:00 PM in London, it’s 5:30 PM in Delhi. Easy peasy!
normalised: Hey everyone, someone asked about time zones in India and how they work, so figured I'd give a quick explanation. It's actually simpler than you might think! India officially follows Indian Standard Time (I-S-T), which is G-M-T plus five thirty. This means we're always five and a half hours ahead of Greenwich Mean Time. So, if it's twelve P-M in London, it's five thirty P-M in Delhi. Easy peasy!

unnormalised: Now, you might wonder, why only one time zone for such a big country? Well, India spans quite a large longitude, and some folks, especially in the North East like Guwahati or Arunachal Pradesh, actually feel that sunrise comes really early. There have been discussions about having a separate time zone for the NE states (+6:30 maybe?), but nothing's been implemented yet. It's mainly a logistical thing, impacting train schedules and communications nationwide.

unnormalised: It's interesting to note that during the British Raj, India actually had 2 time zones! There was Bombay Time (GMT+4:51) and Calcutta Time (GMT+5:53:20) in addition to the IST. Imagine the confusion trying to schedule calls across those regions! Glad we've simplified things since then.

Glad we've simplified things since then.
